Rajiv Gandhi Cancer Institute & Research Centre

patient_stories.Story: Mr. Chhitim Kessang, a 61-year-old male residing in Dehradun, self-referred to the Himalayan Institute of Medical Sciences Hospital, Jolly Grant, Dehradun, with complaints of chest pain, cough, and difficulty in breathing for the past six months. He was admitted, and an MRI of the chest, lung biopsy, CT thorax, and blood investigations were conducted. The results led to a diagnosis of squamous cell lung cancer, and initial treatment was provided at the hospital. However, due to limited medical facilities, he was later referred to Rajiv Gandhi Cancer Institute and Research Centre, Delhi, for further treatment. In November 2020, he contacted the Tibetan Cancer Society for both physical and financial support. We then accompanied him to Rajiv Gandhi Cancer Institute and Research Centre, where further tests—including blood tests, a lung biopsy, and a PET scan—confirmed a diagnosis of metastatic lung cancer. He was immediately started on treatment under the care of Dr. Sumit Goyal. To date, he has undergone 10 cycles of radiation therapy and 3 cycles of chemotherapy. In February 2021, he also underwent an ultrasound-guided nerve block due to frequent episodes of severe pain, despite the use of analgesics. As the patient had long wished to visit the pilgrimage site of Rewalsar (Tso Pema), we took him there to fulfill his last wish. During the visit, we explored the sacred sites together and stayed for about four days. He expressed deep gratitude and joy upon leaving Rewalsar. However, due to his physical weakness, he chose not to undergo further chemotherapy. At that time, all three staff nurses took turns caring for Pala Chhitim, including staying with him overnight. In time, Pala Chhitim passed away peacefully. We honored his final journey with deep respect and affection, offering him a heartfelt and compassionate farewell.

Ven Thupten Namgyal, residing in Bodhgaya, was recently diagnosed with COVID-19, presenting with breathing difficulty and low oxygen saturation. He contacted the Tibetan Cancer Society in October 2020 during the pandemic, requesting emergency ambulance service to visit a hospital in Delhi for medical treatment. Immediately, our team responded and covered a distance of about 2176 km without any rest to provide the emergency ambulance service. We took the risk of handling a COVID-positive patient during such a critical time. Had they booked another ambulance, it would have cost them a substantial amount of money, but we provided the service free of charge. In fact, if it hadnt been for our ambulance, the patient may not have survived. During the pandemic, taking a patient to a private hospital was extremely risky, but after arriving in Delhi, our team immediately took him to the AIIMS Trauma Centre. He was admitted to the ICU for several days and, after one week, was transferred to the general ward for about three days. He was eventually discharged from the hospital and returned safely to his home after recovery. Had they arranged for another ambulance, the transportation cost from Bodhgaya to Delhi would have been exorbitant. We are proud that we could support him during this challenging time, ensuring his safe transport and treatment.

patient_stories.To: Rajiv Gandhi Cancer Institute and Research Centre
patient_stories.Story: Ani Choeying Dolma, a resident of Dharamsala and a known case of stomach cancer, had undergone partial gastrostomy 1–2 years ago. She contacted the Tibetan Cancer Society after experiencing complaints of constipation, lower abdominal pain, vomiting, and decreased food intake over the past few days. Our team immediately responded and traveled for about 24 hours continuously in our ambulance vehicle, covering a distance of 952 km without any rest to provide emergency ambulance service to the patient. Had they booked another ambulance, it would have cost them around Rs 10,000–20,000, but we provided the service free of charge. Upon arriving in Delhi, we took her to the Rajiv Gandhi Cancer Institute and Research Centre, where a physician advised that she required a colostomy. Seeking a second opinion, we then took her to Fortis Hospital, where Dr. Amit Javed, a gastro-onco surgeon, prescribed medication. After taking the prescribed medicines for a few days, her condition improved, her complaints subsided, and her bowel patterns became regular. We followed up with a visit to Fortis Hospital, where the physician confirmed that surgery was not required at that time. However, he mentioned that if she experienced intestinal obstruction in the future, surgery might be necessary. Thanks to our ambulance service, we were able to provide timely medical care without delay. She later returned home, feeling relieved from her symptoms.

Mr. Tenzin Thupten, a 31-year-old male from Dharamsala, who was residing in Delhi at the Punjab Basti shelter home as a destitute, was found unresponsive, as reported by his friend. On the morning of 21st February 2021, the Tibetan Cancer Society team received a call from the shelter home reporting the unresponsive patient. We immediately went to the shelter home, checked the patients vital signs, and assessed the Glasgow Coma Scale, but he remained unresponsive. We attempted to resuscitate him, but there was still no response. Without delay, we provided emergency ambulance service and transported the patient to Aruna Asif Ali Government Hospital. Upon arrival, his vital signs were checked, and an ECG was performed. Unfortunately, the patient was declared deceased at the hospital. We then informed the patient’s family members of his passing, and two of them arrived the following day. On 22nd February 2021, we transported the deceased's body in our ambulance and made arrangements for cremation at Nigambodh Ghat.

Mr. Kunchok Thabgel, a 48-year-old male, suffered 25% scald burns after falling into hot oil on 19th January 2021 due to giddiness and fatigue. He contacted the Tibetan Cancer Society for emergency ambulance service. Our team immediately transported him to Safdarjung Burns Emergency, where he was admitted and treated in the Burns ICU from 19th to 24th January 2021. On 28th January 2021, he slipped in the bathroom and injured his forehead. He again contacted us, and we took him to Safdarjung Hospital, where his forehead was sutured. He is now receiving daily wound dressing at the Primary Health Centre, Majnu-Ka-Tilla.

On the evening of 15th March 2023, the Tibetan Cancer Society (TCS) Director, along with ambulance driver Mr. Tashi Topgyal and Nurse Ms. Tenzin Dekyong, embarked on an urgent emergency rescue mission. The journey commenced from the TCS office in Delhi to the STNM Hospital in Gangtok, Sikkim — a distance of over 1,500 kilometres. The ambulance set out in the evening of 15th March, navigating through the Lucknow Highway and crossing multiple states including Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and West Bengal, before finally entering Sikkim by the evening of 16th March. The team operated on rotational driving shifts between the TCS Director and the ambulance driver, without rest, to ensure continuous movement. By 3:00 a.m. on 17th March, the ambulance successfully reached STNM Hospital in Gangtok. During the journey, the team was informed that the patients condition had deteriorated further. Upon medical evaluation the following day and consultation with Dr. Yougyal, it was sadly confirmed that the patients liver condition had worsened significantly. The patient was placed on a ventilator, rendering it too risky to continue with transportation to Delhi. With a unanimous decision from the patients family and the attending doctors, it was agreed not to proceed with the transfer. Though disheartening, it was ultimately the most medically sound decision. In consultation with our TCS team members and doctors, we spoke with and consoled the patients family regarding the decision. Given the critical circumstances, it was the most appropriate course of action. TCS assured them that theyve done their best. As the TCS team prepared to return to Delhi, the ambulance encountered severe mechanical issues, including damage to the wheel system. At this critical juncture, a Ladakhi Amala (Sikkim) and her family provided remarkable hospitality and assistance. They offered the team shelter, warm meals, and comfort without hesitation. Taking full responsibility, they even arranged for the damaged ambulance to be sent to Siliguri for urgent repairs. During this time, generous support was also extended by Dr. Yougyal, Cho Karma, and a local team of mechanics in Sikkim. The patient’s son kindly offered to bear the full cost of repairs, a gesture deeply appreciated by the TCS team, though politely declined. Although the primary mission to transport the patient to Delhi could not be completed, the TCS team remains proud of their effort and dedication. Despite the physical toll — with minimal rest and sleep — the mission was pursued with sincere commitment to the cause. In the spirit of service, TCS publicly announced through social media and community groups that the ambulance would be available free of charge for future critical patients from Sikkim requiring transportation to Delhi, regardless of ethnicity. The mission, though marked by unforeseen challenges, stands as a testament to the unwavering commitment of the Tibetan Cancer Society to serve those in need.

Ambulance1.event: On the auspicious occasion of Gandhi Jayanti, 2nd October 2020, the Tibetan Cancer Society (TCS) proudly inaugurated its first ambulance, marking a significant milestone in its mission to serve the Tibetan community. The inauguration ceremony was graced by the presence of Chandni Chowk MLA Shri Parlad Singh Sawhney, along with several distinguished guests and representatives from various organizations. The event reflected the vision of the organization, emphasizing the importance of the ambulance service in enhancing healthcare access for the Tibetan community in Delhi and beyond. The ribbon-cutting ceremony was honored by Shri Sawhney ji, who then delivered a few encouraging and heartfelt words in appreciation of the work done by the Tibetan Cancer Society. He expressed his admiration for the initiative and extended his continued support and commitment to assist the Tibetan community in the future. As a gesture of gratitude, he presented mementos to the Sameyling Tibetan Settlement Officer, NGO leaders, and other key supporters who played an essential role in organizing the event and consistently supporting the societys mission. Following the speeches, Mr. Tsultrim Dorjee la gave a detailed briefing on the significance of introducing an ambulance service, explaining how it would serve as a life-saving tool, especially for cancer patients, and elaborated on the ambulance policies. The program commenced at 12:00 PM with the arrival of Shri Sawhney ji. Tea and refreshments were served to the guests, followed by a brief orientation presented by Mr. Tsultrim Dorjee la, CEO of Tibetan Cancer Society, who outlined the objectives.

Ambulance2.event: On Sunday, September 5, 2021, Kyabje Lelung Rinpoche of the Lelung Dharma Trust donated a fully-equipped emergency ambulance to the Tibetan Cancer Society based in Delhi. The donation ceremony took place at the TCV Day School in Samyeling Tibetan Colony, Delhi. The donation was prompted by Rinpoche's deep concern regarding the severe conditions during the second wave of the COVID-19 pandemic in India, which originated in Wuhan, China. During this period, India faced critical shortages, including insufficient wood for cremating the bodies of those deceased people. The ambulance, described as a modern, standard emergency vehicle equipped with all necessary facilities for saving lives in emergency situations, was donated with the hope of alleviating some of these emergency situations and reducing casualties. Mr. Tsultrim Dorje, Chairman of the Tibetan Cancer Society, expressed gratitude to the Lelung Charitable Foundation and Kyabje Lelung Rinpoche on behalf of their organization and the entire Tibetan community. He explained the importance and benefits of ambulance services during emergency situations and noted that the Tibetan Cancer Society now has two ambulances—one stationed in Mysore city to serve four Tibetan settlements in South India, and the newly donated vehicle that will remain permanently in Delhi. The ceremony was attended by representatives from Tibetan NGOs and the Samyeling Tibetan Colony's representative. Former Deputy Speaker of the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, Acharya Yeshi Phuntsok, attended as a special guest. The Tibetan Cancer Society also presented certificates to volunteers and donors who had provided assistance during the second wave of the COVID-19 pandemic. During the donation ceremony, Lelung Rinpoche expressed his foundation's aspirations to launch extensive construction projects in Delhi for homeless Tibetan youth, aimed at preserving their religious culture and traditions while preventing cultural dispersion. Rinpoche acknowledged that while these plans have not yet been implemented, he hopes they will be realized in the future. Rinpoche honored the Tibetan Cancer Society for their continued service to the community and emphasized the importance of Tibetans helping each other regardless of racial or ethnic backgrounds, noting that Tibetans traditionally regard all sentient beings without discrimination.
